review.title: Overcoming Language Variation in Sentiment Analysis with Social Attention
review.abstract: Variation in language is ubiquitous, and is particularly evident in newer forms of writing such as social media. Fortunately, variation is not random, but is usually linked to social factors. By exploiting linguistic homophily --- the tendency of socially linked individuals to use language similarly --- it is possible to build models that are more robust to variation. In this paper, we focus on social network communities, which make it possible to generalize sociolinguistic properties from authors in the training set to authors in the test sets, without requiring demographic author metadata. We detect communities via standard graph clustering algorithms, and then exploit these communities by learning community-specific projections of word embeddings. These projections capture shifts in word meaning in different social groups; by modeling them, we are able to improve the overall accuracy of Twitter sentiment analysis by a significant margin over competitive prior work.

sections.heading: 2 Community Detection
sections.text: Community recognition in networks aims to identify clusters or / and their hierarchical organization by using only the information encoded in network topology (as shown in Figure 2), a problem of considerable interest in many areas, with applications to food networks, citation networks, social networks and the Web; in the NLP context, community recognition is usually treated as an optimization problem, where the objective function captures the intuition of a network community as a set of nodes with better internal connectivity than external connectivity. Specifically, many of the best-known community recognition algorithms seek to maximize modularity that compares the density of edges within communities with the density of edges between communities (Newman, 2006).

sections.heading: 2.1 Community Detection Algorithms
sections.text: Fast-Greedy Fast-Greedy is a hierarchical approach that recognizes communities in a bottom-up way (Clauset et al., 2004). First, each node belongs to a separate community, and communities are merged iteratively so that each merge is locally optimal. Specifically, in each iteration, the algorithm scans over each edge that connects two separate communities in the current configuration, and calculates the increase in the current value of modularity by merging the two communities.

sections.heading: 2.2 Linguistic Modularity in Social Network Communities
sections.text: After focusing on the recognition of communities as a summary of social network structures, we refine this hypothesis to linguistic modularity: the linguistic similarity should be higher for pairs of individuals in the same community than for pairs of individuals in different communities. To formalize linguistic modularity, we follow the traditional definition of modularity in social networks. Suppose we get a social network G on which we induce a communal structure C = {ci}. We now create an alternative network G (L) that represents linguistic similarity. InG (L) each node has an advantage over the K that is most linguistically similar, with linguistic similarity measured by TF-IDF weighted cosmic similarity.

sections.heading: 3 Testing Linguistic Modularity
sections.text: We evaluate the linguistic modularity of FastGreedy and multi-level community detection algorithms in a social network constructed from the SemEval Twitter Sentiment Analysis Review. Specifically, we start with the users in the SemEval data sets and then use the Twitter API to search their friend links as undirected edges (in Twitter terminology, the "friends" of an individual are accounts that the individual follows).The statistics of this network are shown in the first row of Table 1. As shown, the average degree for each node is less than three, and more than 25% of the authors are isolated, meaning that they have no social network connections. For these users, the social network cannot provide any useful information.One approach to increase the density of the social network would be to crawl additional nodes through snowball sampling (Goodman, 1961): specifically, we would expand the group of nodes to include all friends of the original network in the eval.

sections.heading: 3.1 Quantifying linguistic modularity
sections.text: We measure the linguistic modularity as described in subsection 2.2 on the SEMEVAL and SEMEVAL + networks, using the Fast-Greedy and Multi-Level Community Recognition algorithms. Linguistic information was calculated from each author's most recent 3,200 tweets, and the G (L) linguistic network was constructed by building edges to the five closest neighbors. We merge all communities with fewer than ten users into a single community, which consists largely of isolates, and the number of communities is automatically selected in all cases by the algorithm. Results are presented in Table 2. All results are significantly higher than zero using a bootstrap resampling test, p 0.001, suggesting that the hypothesis of linguistic modularity applies to this data and to both community recognition algorithms. Linguistic modularity is significantly higher than modularity for SEMEVAL +, which indicates that the quality of the user's additional point of a creep is valid.

sections.heading: 4 Community-specific Word Embeddings
sections.text: In this section, we propose to use social network community structures to improve NLP tasks. We build on the successful non-linear Subspace Embedding (NLSE) model, which learns a task-specific projection matrix to apply to upstream word embedding (Astudillo et al., 2015), hj = sigmoid (Swj), (2) where wj-Rd is an upstream word embedding for word j, and S-Rk × d is the task-specific projection structure, with d and k indicating the size of upstream and projected word embedding. The advantage of this approach is that the upstream word embedding can be learned from large amounts of unlabeled text, while supervised training is only necessary to learn the s-d-matrix-S and the final classification weights.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper presents a new method of learning to overcome language variations by leveraging the tendency of individuals with similar linguistic patterns to share social networking connections - the phenomenon of linguistic homophilia. By learning separate projections of word embeddings for each community, our approach is able to capture subtle shifts in meaning for individual words in social communities. We have formulated this model by building on preparatory work that learns task-specific projections of word embeddings; we go further by learning predictions that are both task-specific and community-specific. A key question for future work is whether the task and community dimensions can be decoupled: Can we learn a community-based projection that is useful for multiple tasks? To answer this question, basic truth annotations for multiple tasks for socially connected authors are needed. This could possibly be achieved by adding a layer of annotations on top of the eval form of Twitter data set, or by planning to include these social favorites in a very specific direction.
